description.plain:
2 Live Crew is known as the notorious rap group that first took pornographic rap not only into the mainstream, but the jailhouse and courtroom. Originally a California-based hip hop group consisting of rappers Amazing Vee and Fresh Kid Ice with DJ Mr Mixx, their 1984 debut single “The Revelation” became popular in Florida, so record label owner Luther “Luke Skyywalker” Campbell helped the group relocate there. Vee chose not to participate.

Two more singles, “What I Like” and “Throw The D(ick)”, were released before Vee’s spot was filled by Brother Marquis. Their debut album 2 Live Is What We Are had some explicit songs like “We Want Some Pussy” and “Get It Girl” which gave the band an underground following and a reputation for smutty lyrics at a time when tamer songs were being heavily attacked by the newly-formed PMRC.

Campbell joined the group as an official hype man and spokesperson before the release of their 1988 sophomore album Move Somethin', an album that would fully transform the group from occasionally releasing vulgar songs into an all-out pornographic rap group. The album was the first ever to be sold in both explicit and edited versions. Authorities began unsuccessfully trying to penalize record store clerks who sold it.

In 1989, 2 Live Crew released their third album As Nasty As They Wanna Be (along with its somewhat milder companion As Clean As They Wanna Be). Its lead single “Me So Horny” was a crossover top 30 pop hit in the US and gave the pornographic album a mainstream audience. This attracted the attention of not only the PMRC but Florida attorney/activist Jack Thompson, who engineered a campaign that led to the album being labelled obscene in Lee County, Florida, and therefore illegal to sell or perform live there.

Thompson then fired off letters with copies of lyrics to governors and sheriff’s departments, prompting judges all over Florida, as well as in counties in six other states, to issue similar rulings. In June of 1990, a Fort Lauderdale record store owner was arrested for selling the album to an undercover police officer, and members of the group were arrested in Miami for performing songs from it. Eventually a jury acquitted the group.

These incidents inspired some of the songs on the group’s next album Banned In The USA (originally released as Luke featuring 2 Live Crew) like “Fuck Martinez” (referring to then-Florida governor Bob Martinez) and its top 20 title track which sampled Bruce Springsteen’s mega-hit “Born In The USA” with his explicit permission and ‘enthusiastic’ support. Banned In The USA remains the group’s highest charting album, reaching #21 in the summer of 1990. This would be the peak of the band’s mainstream notoriety.

2 Live Crew’s next effort Sports Weekend (As Nasty As They Wanna Be Part 2) was also accompanied by a companion album with somewhat cleaned-up lyrics. Its lead single “Pop That Coochie” (aka “Pop That Pussy”) reached #58 on the pop chart, and the album peaked one spot lower than Banned In The USA in late 1991. The album was certified gold seven months later, but the group’s popularity began to wane.

1994’s Back at Your Ass for the Nine-4 was released without Marquis and Mr Mixx under the name The New 2 Live Crew. It was their first not to be certified at least gold, and it had no pop crossover hits. 1996’s Shake a Lil' Somethin' saw the classic lineup reunite. Its title track peaked at #72, becoming the group’s last Hot 100 appearance. 1998’s The Real One did not include Mr Mixx and would make less impact than both of its predecessors. Music output since has been sporadic.

In 2010, Campbell revealed that Mr Mixx is not allowed to perform 2 Live Crew songs or even say he was a member of the group, due to “a 6-year-old slimy-as-hell settlement agreement” with the company that bought the rights to the music. Fresh Kid Ice passed away in 2017.

songs.full_title: Me So Horny by 2 Live Crew
songs.title: Me So Horny

description.plain:
“Me So Horny” is the first single from 2 Live Crew’s groundbreaking, law-breaking, highly controversial and successful third album As Nasty As They Wanna Be. It was the group’s first of two top 30 US pop hits and it held the top spot on the US Rap Chart for four weeks.

This song along with tracks like “Put Her In The Buck”, and “The Fuck Shop” led anti-pornography Florida lawyer Jack Thompson to take the group to court after engineering a campaign that led to the album, with its 87 descriptions of oral sex and 116 descriptions of male and female genitalia, being labelled obscene in Lee County, Florida, and therefore illegal to sell or perform live there.

In June of 1990, a Fort Lauderdale record store owner was arrested for selling the album to an undercover police officer, and members of the group were arrested in Miami for performing songs from it. Eventually a jury acquitted the group.

The main music sample used in “Me So Horny” is from Mass Production’s “Firecracker” off their 1979 album In the Purest Form. The line “Me So Horny” was taken from the 1987 film Full Metal Jacket.

songs.full_title: Dirty Nursery Rhymes by 2 Live Crew
songs.title: Dirty Nursery Rhymes

description.plain:
“Dirty Nursery Rhymes” is a collection of rhymes based on old nursery rhymes and other children’s stories that have been made perverted.

Andrew Dice Clay – a stand-up comic who was at the peak of his fame around this time (in 1990, the year after As Nasty As They Wanna Be came out, he became the first comedian ever to sell out Madison Square Garden two nights in a row). His most famous routine involved X-rated rewrites of Mother Goose nursery rhymes. On this song, the Crew steal a page from his playbook.

songs.full_title: The Fuck Shop by 2 Live Crew
songs.title: The Fuck Shop

description.plain:
“The Fuck Shop” was the third single from 2 Live Crew’s massive album As Nasty As They Wanna Be. A cleaner version of the song titled “The Funk Shop” (found on As Clean As The Wanna Be) peaked at #14 on the US Rap Chart in the spring of 1990.

The song samples Van Halen’s “Ain’t Talkin' ‘bout Love”, Guns N’ Roses’s “Sweet Child o' Mine”, two lines from Skillet & Leroy & LaWanda’s Back Door Daddy, and The Music Explosion’s “Little Bit o' Soul”.

songs.full_title: Fuck Martinez by 2 Live Crew
songs.title: Fuck Martinez

description.plain:
“Fuck Martinez” addresses former Florida governor Bob Martinez, his wife, and former sheriff of Broward County, Florida, Nick Navarro.

Governor Martinez ordered state prosecutors to determine whether or not 2 Live Crew’s prior album As Nasty As They Wanna Be violated Florida obscenity laws. The album was deemed obscene and record store owners were arrested for selling the album, as were members of the group for performing songs from the album in concert. Sheriff Navarro was the arresting officer in all cases, of which they were all eventually acquitted.

The actions of Governor Martinez and Sheriff Navarro ultimately led to Banned in the USA becoming the first album with the black & white Parental Advisory sticker on the front that is so common today.

“Fuck Martinez” is the only track on Banned in the U.S.A. that’s not a traditional rap song, interlude or DJ mix. Aside from some ad-libs, the entire song is performed in a call and response and call and repeat format. It’s also the only song that utilized a bleep censor on the edited version of the album, every other song was either removed from the edited version, re-recorded with alternate lyrics or had the explicit words backmasked to make the fact that the album was edited less obvious.

By using the simple, repetitive phrases required for songs of this format and utilizing a bleep censor that calls attention to the fact that the song contains explicit lyrics, 2 Live Crew ensured that the vulgar nature of the insults directed at those who censored their prior album would be obvious, even in the “clean” version of the album.

The censored version of “Fuck Martinez” (simply titled “Martinez”) can be heard below.

https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=fvAB-_C_Il4

songs.full_title: Pretty Woman by 2 Live Crew
songs.title: Pretty Woman

description.plain:
The song is a parody of Roy Orbion’s 1964 hit “Oh, Pretty Woman”.

Label owner Luke Campbell initially tried to get clearance to use elements of the original track, but the song’s publisher refused. He released it anyway on the ‘clean’ version of the group’s third album, and the label found themselves being sued for copyright infringement. However, the Supreme Court ruled in the band’s favor, expanding the scope of protection of parodies, even when written for profit.

songs.full_title: Banned in the U.S.A. by 2 Live Crew
songs.title: Banned in the U.S.A.

description.plain:
“Banned In The USA” was the lead single from its namesake album. It became a top 20 US hit and their highest-charting song. It also reached the top 30 in the Netherlands.

In June of 1990, a Fort Lauderdale record store owner was arrested for selling 2 Live Crew’s explicit third album As Nasty As They Wanna Be to an undercover police officer, and members of the group were arrested in Miami for performing songs from it after Florida attorney/activist Jack Thompson engineered a campaign that led to the album being considered obscene and therefore illegal to sell or perform live. Eventually a jury acquitted the group. These incidents inspired “Banned In The USA”.

The song is notable for sampling Bruce Springsteen’s mega-hit “Born In The USA”, for which the band got his permission and ‘enthusiastic’ support.

description.plain: “C'mon Babe” was the second single released from the groundbreaking, law-breaking, breakthrough album As Nasty As They Wanna Be, following the top 30 pop crossover success of “Me So Horny”. A clean(er) version of the song was recorded for the milder As Clean As They Wanna Be – it is that version that was released officially as a single for radio play and reached #7 on the US Rap Chart in March of 1990.

songs.full_title: Do Wah Diddy by 2 Live Crew
songs.title: Do Wah Diddy

description.plain:
“Do Wah Diddy” is the second single from Move Somethin'. It peaked at #62 on the US R&B/Hip-Hop chart in late 1988. It heavily samples the chart-topping 1963 Manfred Mann hit “Do Wah Diddy” and its lyrical structure also follows the original.

Its b-side is the rare song “I Can’t Go For That”, only ever released on this 12" record, which heavily samples the Hall & Oates song “I Can’t Go For That (No Can Do)”.

songs.full_title: Throw the 'D' by 2 Live Crew
songs.title: Throw the ‘D’

description.plain:
This was not only the first certified Gold record by 2 Live Crew, but also the single that founded Luke Skyywalker Records. It was recorded in California independently by Fresh Kid Ice and Mr Mixx for just over $200. Fresh Kid Ice wrote the rap on a red eye flight from a weekend of performing 2 Live Crew shows in Miami on his way with Mr Mixx back to March Air Force Base in Riverside, California where they were both stationed in the military.

Luke Skyywalker was unable to convince Miami record labels to press the record, so he decided to do it himself, and Luke Skyywalker Records was born.

songs.full_title: Move Somethin' by 2 Live Crew
songs.title: Move Somethin’

description.plain:
“Move Somethin'” is the first single and title track of 2 Live Crew’s second album. A clean version of the song was released to radio and peaked at #53 on the US R&B/Hip-Hop Chart in the summer of 1988.

On its flipside is the song “Head, Booty & Cock” (which was listed on some releases of the album Move Somethin' simply as “H-B-C”).

songs.title: I Ain’t Bullshittin’

description.plain:
This is the first in a series of spoken-word tracks where Luke airs his gripes about everyone and everything pissing him off. Here he takes aim at members of the New York hip hop community who’ve ridiculed 2 Live Crew and refuse to take them seriously.

Similar tracks appear in the subsequent 2 Live Crew album Sports Weekend and on Luke’s first two solo efforts, Banned in the USA and I Got Shit on My Mind.

“Mamo La Penga” is Spanish for “suck the penis”.

Brother Marquis meets Juanita, a provocatively-dressed but good, wholesome Catholic girl, while strolling through Little Havana. By the end of the night, Juanita is in a threesome with Marquis and Mr. Mixx.

songs.full_title: The Funk Shop by 2 Live Crew
songs.title: The Funk Shop

description.plain:
Cleaner version of “The Fuck Shop” from As Nasty As They Wanna Be. This version peaked at #14 on the US Rap Chart in the spring of 1990.

The song samples Van Halen’s “Ain’t Talkin' ‘bout Love”, Guns N' Roses’s “Sweet Child O' Mine”, two lines from Skillet & Leroy & LaWanda’s Back Door Daddy, and The Music Explosion’s “Little Bit o' Soul”.

“The Funk Shop” was not included on the original releases of As Clean As They Wanna Be, but after they were forced to remove “Pretty Woman” from the album due to a lawsuit over its use of an uncleared sample, this track took its place.

songs.full_title: Coolin' by 2 Live Crew
songs.title: Coolin’

description.plain:
“Coolin” closes out As Nasty As They Wanna Be with a less vulgar vibe than most of the songs on the album. It simply recounts some pleasant events the group has experienced. The track heavily samples “Soulful Strut” by Young-Holt Unlimited.

It was released as a single in the UK, but did not chart.

songs.full_title: Who's Fuckin' Who by 2 Live Crew
songs.title: Who’s Fuckin’ Who

description.plain:
“Who’s Fuckin' Who” shows 2 Live Crew showing concern for the spread of STD’s, warning people to take precautions when having sex. It’s title is a play on the Aretha Franklin 1985 hit “Who’s Zoomin' Who”.

The music is taken from the 1973 chart-topper “Brother Louie” by The Stories. It also samples Bob James “Take Me to the Mardi Gras”.

A clean version was released to radio as the album’s second single under the title “Who’s Doin' Who”. Some releases included instructions on how to put a condom on. The song did not chart.

songs.full_title: Yakety Yak by 2 Live Crew
songs.title: Yakety Yak

description.plain:
“Yakety Yak” is 2 Live Crew’s contribution of the soundtrack for the film Twins. It heavily samples the 1958 chart-topper of the same name by The Coasters.

The song did not appear on any of their studio albums, being released in early 1989 between their second album Move Somethin' and their third and most successful As Nasty As They Wanna Be.

“Yakety Yak” is the 2 Live Crew’s only song to chart in the UK, peaking at #90. It also reached #22 on the US Rap Songs Chart.

songs.full_title: I Can't Go for That by 2 Live Crew
songs.title: I Can’t Go for That

description.plain: “I Can’t Go For That” is a rare 2 Live Crew song that was only ever released on the 12" single for “Do Wah Diddy”, the second single from the group’s second album Move Somethin'. It heavily samples the Hall & Oates song “I Can’t Go For That (No Can Do)”.
